dt: {bc}to begin to occur or to exist {bc}to come into being or to attention

dt.t: Problems {wi}arise{/wi} when people try to avoid responsibility.
A conflict {wi}arose{/wi} because of a misunderstanding.
Questions have {wi}arisen{/wi} concerning the company's financial records.
He can defend himself {phrase}should the need arise{/phrase}. {gloss}=if it becomes necessary to do so{/gloss}
a river that {wi}arises{/wi} from two main sources

dt: {bc}to get up from sleep or after lying down

dt.t: He {it}arose{/it} (from bed) refreshed after a good night's sleep.

pt: {sc}spring{/sc} {sc}arise{/sc} {sc}rise{/sc} {sc}originate{/sc} {sc}derive{/sc} {sc}flow{/sc} {sc}issue{/sc} {sc}emanate{/sc} {sc}proceed{/sc} {sc}stem{/sc} mean to come up or out of something into existence. {sc}spring{/sc} implies rapid or sudden emerging.
{sc}arise{/sc} and {sc}rise{/sc} may both convey the fact of coming into existence or notice but {sc}rise{/sc} often stresses gradual growth or ascent.
{sc}originate{/sc} implies a definite source or starting point.
{sc}derive{/sc} implies a prior existence in another form.

pt.t: the holiday {it}derives{/it} from an ancient Roman feast

pt: {sc}flow{/sc} adds to {sc}spring{/sc} a suggestion of abundance or ease of inception.
{sc}issue{/sc} suggests emerging from confinement through an outlet.
{sc}emanate{/sc} applies to the coming of something immaterial (such as a thought) from a source.
{sc}proceed{/sc} stresses place of origin, derivation, parentage, or logical cause.

pt.t: advice that {it}proceeds{/it} from the best of intentions

pt: {sc}stem{/sc} implies originating by dividing or branching off from something as an outgrowth or subordinate development.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}ārīsan{/it}, from {it}ā-{/it}, perfective prefix + {it}rīsan{/it} to rise {ma}{mat|abide|}{/ma}
shortdef: to begin to occur or to exist : to come into being or to attention
to get up or stand up : rise; especially : to get up from sleep or after lying down

meta.id: come out/up smelling like a rose
stems: come out smelling like a rose
come out/up smelling like a rose
come up smelling like a rose

hwi.hw: come out/up smelling like a rose

dt: {bc}to have success or good fortune in a situation in which one was likely to fail, be harmed, etc.

dt.t: The scandal forced several board members to resign, but the chairman {it}came out smelling like a rose{/it}.

shortdef: to have success or good fortune in a situation in which one was likely to fail, be harmed, etc.
